org.beiter.michael.eaudit4j.common

Interface Audit

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    SyncAudit

    public interface Audit
    The audit chain combines one or more processors into an input / output sequence of processors. When an event is submitted to an audit chain, the event is passed through all processors that are part of the audit chain, and the output of a first processor is used as the input of a second processor.

    Implementations of this interface may produce synchronous or asynchronous audit chains.

    Classes implementing this interface must be thread safe.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      Event audit(Event event)
      This method processes an event in the default audit stream.

      Event audit(Event event, String auditStreamName, ProcessingObjects processingObjects)

      void init(CommonProperties properties)
      Initializes the audit chain configuration

    • Method Detail

      • init

        void init(CommonProperties properties)
   throws AuditException
        Initializes the audit chain configuration

        A class implementing this interface must provide a reasonable default configuration and handle situations where the interface's methods are called without a previous call of init() (i.e. do not throw a runtime exception).

        A class implementing this interface must ensure that subsequent calls to this method update the class' configuration in a thread-safe way.

        Parameters:
        properties - The properties to initialize the audit chain with. Supported "additionalParameters" may vary with the implementing classes.
        Throws:
        AuditException - When the initialization fails

      • audit

        Event audit(Event event)
     throws AuditException
        This method processes an event in the default audit stream.

        The event may be modified by the processors contained in the audit stream. When the event has been processed, it is returned to the caller.

        Note that in asynchronous implementations of this interface, the behavior is undefined. The returned event may be, for instance, the originally provided event (or a copy thereof), or simply null.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to audit
        Returns:
        The event after processing (for synchronous audit implementations), undefined otherwise
        Throws:
        AuditException - when the audit operation fails

      • audit

        Event audit(Event event,
            String auditStreamName)
     throws AuditException
        This method processes an event in the provided audit stream.

        Applications may support more than one audit streams. Audit streams are event streams that are isolated from each other. As an example, an application may want to support one audit stream per tenant, plus one or more additional audit streams for global events, allowing sharing of audit data with tenants without the risk of compromising other tenants but still maintaining full integrity of the shared audit data.

        The event may be modified by the processors contained in the audit stream. When the event has been processed, it is returned to the caller.

        Note that in asynchronous implementations of this interface, the behavior is undefined. The returned event may be, for instance, the originally provided event (or a copy thereof), or simply null.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to audit
        auditStreamName - The audit stream to send events to
        Returns:
        The event after processing (for synchronous audit implementations), undefined otherwise
        Throws:
        AuditException - when the audit operation fails

      • audit

        Event audit(Event event,
            String auditStreamName,
            ProcessingObjects processingObjects)
     throws AuditException
        This method processes an event in the provided audit stream and includes a set of ProcessingObjects.

        ProcessingObjects allow an application to inject a set of named objects into the processor. This is commonly used for objects that are managed by applications, and cannot or should not be created by an individual Processor.

        Examples for such objects include DataSource objects to connect to a database, with the database connection pool being managed directly by the application.

        The event may be modified by the processors contained in the audit stream. When the event has been processed, it is returned to the caller.

        Note that in asynchronous implementations of this interface, the behavior is undefined. The returned event may be, for instance, the originally provided event (or a copy thereof), or simply null.

        Parameters:
        event - The event to be processed
        auditStreamName - The audit stream to send events to
        processingObjects - The processing objects available to the processors
        Returns:
        The event after processing (for synchronous audit implementations), undefined otherwise
        Throws:
        AuditException - when the audit operation fails
